questions.text: In which of the following conditions is hypothalamic amenorrhea typically seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kallmann Syndrome is a form of hypothalamic amenorrhea are caused by deficiency of GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) secretion from the hypothalamus.Often associated with anosmia/hyposmia (loss or decrease in sense of smell).
  • Leads to low GnRH → low FSH & LH → low estrogen → primary amenorrhea and absent or delayed puberty.

Kallmann syndrome may be associated with:

  • Optic atrophy
  • Color blindness
  • Nerve deafness
  • Cleft palate
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Neurologic abnormalities

Management: Cyclical estrogen/progestin therapy or gonadotropins.

Explanation of other options:

  • Asherman Syndrome(Option A):Uterine cause of amenorrhea due to intrauterine adhesions (usually post-curettage) Normal hypothalamic-pituitary axis.
  • Stein-Leventhal Syndrome (PCOS)(Option B):Ovarian cause of anovulation, but not hypothalamic.GnRH secretion is increased (↑ LH:FSH ratio), not deficient.
  • Sheehan's Syndrome(Option D):It is due to a Pituitary cause of amenorrhea and the pathology being postpartum pituitary infarction → panhypopituitarism leading to Low FSH/LH, but from pituitary failure, not hypothalamic.

questions.text: A 12-year-old young girl presents in the casualty with acute pain in the lower abdomen. She has a history of cyclical pain for the last 5 months and she has not attained her menarche yet. The given image shows the local genital examination . The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A young girl who has not attained menarche but has a history of cyclical pain for the last 6 months, presenting to casualty with acute abdomen and on examination a tense bulge in the region of hymen clearly point towards "Imperforate hymen" as the diagnosis.

Explanation:

  • Sheehan's syndrome is postpartum pituitary necrosis. It leads to secondary amenorrhea and not primary amenorrhea.
  • Kallmann's syndrome is due to hypothalamic dysfunction characterised by a deficiency of gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) causing a hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This is associated with anosmia. It can occasionally be associated with optic problems, such as color blindness or optic atrophy, nerve deafness, cleft palate, cryptorchidism, renal agenesis, and mirror movement disorder.(Option B ruled out)
  • MRKH syndrome, also known as Mullerian agenesis, is due to anatomical absence of the uterus. This is the second most common cause of primary amenorrhea(Option C ruled out)
  • Turner's syndrome is a type of gonadal dysgenesis and is overall the most common cause of primary amenorrhea(Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Metastasis to pituitary from another carcinoma

questions.text: A woman has 2 kids. She presents with galactorrhea and amenorrhea for 1 year. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The female in the question is presenting with galactorrhea and amenorrhea for 1 year which raises the suspicion of raised prolactin levels for pituitary tumor i.e. prolactinoma/pituitary adenoma. A woman with 1 year of continuous galactorrhea with amenorrhea is unlikely to have undetected pregnancy and there won't be galactorrhea in Sheenan due to pituitary necrosis. (Option A,C and D ruled out)

Pituitary Adenomas:

  • The most common Pituitary adenoma is Prolactinomas.

Presentation:

  • Women present with:
    • Galactorrhea
    • Features of hypogonadism:
      • Amenorrhea/ Oligomenorrhea (as prolactin inhibits GnRH) :Delayed puberty, Anovulation
      • Infertility
  • In both sexes, they can cause symptoms due to mass effects of the tumor:
    • Cavernous sinus syndrome consisting of: Headaches
    • Visual defects (Most common Bitemporal hemianopsia)
    • Cranial nerve palsies especially III, IV, and VI
    • Raised serum prolactin levels
    • X-Ray sella shows space occupying lesions.
  • Investigations:In all cases of hyperprolactinemia:
    • MRI should be performed
    • TSH levels should be measured

Management:

Microadenoma with no desire of fertility:

  • Asymptomatic patients with microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas and are managed conservatively.
  • If a patient has osteopenia, (due to hypoestrogenemia caused by ↑ Prolactin levels) = estrogen replacement or OCP's.
  • Monitor patients with regular serial prolactin levels and MRI (every 12 months).

For symptomatic microadenomas:

  • Medical management by dopamine agonists viz bromocriptine and cabergoline (which increase dopamine levels, thus decreasing prolactin levels) are the mainstay of therapy.
  • Other dopamine agents like pergolide, lisuride (both ergot derivatives) and quinagolide (non ergot derivative) can also be used.

Macroadenomas:

  • Long-term Bromocriptine therapy with periodic serum prolactin measurements (6 monthly) and MRI (6 monthly).

Surgery indications:

  • Tumors unresponsive to Bromocriptine
  • Tumors causing persistent visual field loss

questions.text: The commonest cause of primary amenorrhoea is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most common cause of Primary Amenorrhea is Gonadal dysgenesis/ovarian dysgenesis
  • 2nd most common cause of Primary Amenorrhea = Mullerian agenesis (Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser Syndrome). (Option C ruled out)
  • Hypothyroidism and Genital tuberculosis are causes of secondary amenorrhea.(Option A and D ruled out)

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient complains of primary amenorrhea. She had well developed breast and pubic hair but on examination there was absence of uterus and vagina. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the question, a 19 year old girl is presenting with primary amenorrhea, she has well developed breast and pubic hair but on examination uterus and vagina are absent. Since her breasts and pubic hair are well developed, her secondary sexual characteristics are normal, indicating adequate estrogen and therefore normally functioning ovaries.
  • Patients with mullerian agenesis, typically present in late adolescence or as young adults, well after menarche was expected, with primary amenorrhea as their only complaint. They exhibit normal, symmetrical breast and pubic hair development, no usable vagina and have no symptoms or signs of cryptomenorrhea because the rudimentary uterus contains no functional endometrium.

Explanation of other options:

  • XYY Syndrome(Option A):Karyotype: 47,XYYPhenotypically normal male.Not associated with amenorrhea or absence of uterus/vagina.
  • Gonadal Dysgenesis(Option C): It includes Turner Syndrome (45,XO) or Swyer Syndrome (46,XY)Patients typically have streak gonads, hence lack estrogen, resulting in poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics and Primary amenorrhea.Uterus present except in Swyer, but then no breast development, hence ruled out.
  • Klinefelter Syndrome (47,XXY)(Option D):It Affects males and has features of Tall stature,Small testes,Gynecomastia and Infertility.Not relevant to primary amenorrhea or uterine agenesis.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhoea with anosmia is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kallmann Syndrome is a form of hypothalamic amenorrhea are caused by deficiency of GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) secretion from the hypothalamus.Often associated with anosmia/hyposmia (loss or decrease in sense of smell).
  • Leads to low GnRH → low FSH & LH → low estrogen → primary amenorrhea and absent or delayed puberty.

Explanation of other options:

  • Laurence Moon Biedl Syndrome(Option B):
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by GnRH deficiency (hypogonadism) (FSH < 40 mIU/ml) and associated with:
    • Obesity
    • Mental retardation
    • Polydactyly
    • Retinitis Pigmentosa
  • Foster Kennedy Syndrome(Option C):
    • It is characterised by papilloedema in one eye and optic atrophy in the other. It results from raised intracranial pressure and simultaneous optic nerve compression secondary to tumor - classically, a meningioma of the olfactory groove, or more commonly, due to meningioma of the sphenoid wing.
  • Sheehan's syndrome(Option D):
    • It is the syndrome which results from ischaemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitary due to spasm in its arterioles occurring at the time of severe haemorrhage or shock complicating childbirth.
    • Only the anterior pituitary is affected because in parturient woman, blood supply to the pituitary gland is modified to the advantage of the posterior lobe and disadvantage of the anterior lobe so, when spasm occurs, the posterior lobe is protected.
    • When 75% of anterior pituitary is destroyed, manifestations of Sheehan's syndrome appear and when 95% is destroyed - fully developed Simmond's syndrome is seen.
    • Hormones of anterior pituitary are affected in order of frequency ,GH, FSH, and LH, TSH and ACTH

questions.text: Withdrawal bleeding with progesterone seen in otherwise amenorrheic woman due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A patient is having positive progesterone challenge i.e. bleeding occurs after giving progesterone it means:
  • The intact hypothalamo-pituitary ovarian axis and there is adequate endogenous estrogens (serum E2 level more than 40 pg/ml) to promote progesterone receptors in the endometrium,
  • Anatomically patent outflow tract and Endometrium is responsive.
  • The defect lies in production of progesterone (as when progesterone is supplemented from outside, it results in withdrawal bleeding) and since progesterone is produced mainly by corpus luteum, so, the defect is anovulation.
  • The main cause of Anovulation in a case of 2° amenorrhea is polycystic ovarian disease.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism(Option A): It is Seen in hypothalamic or pituitary causes (e.g., stress, excessive exercise, weight loss). Low FSH, LH → Low estrogen leads to no endometrial proliferation and no withdrawal bleeding with progesterone challenge.Requires estrogen + progesterone for withdrawal bleeding
  • Ovarian Failure (Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism)(Option C): It is caused by Premature ovarian insufficiency, menopause. FSH & LH are high and estrogen is low. No endometrial proliferation, so no withdrawal bleeding and no estrogen priming thus progesterone challenge is negative.
  • TB Endometritis(Option D): Tubercular infection destroys the endometrial lining,Endometrium may be unresponsive or scarred,No proliferation despite hormones.So, no bleeding even after progesterone challenge

questions.text: A 16 year old child with primary amenorrhea with negative progesterone challenge test but positive combined progesterone and estrogen test. Diagnosis may be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child is presenting with primary amenorrhea with:

  • A positive estrogen-progesterone combined test indicates that the endometrium responds, meaning the uterus and outflow tract are normal.
  • Therefore, the defect lies in estrogen production, i.e., at the level of the ovaries, pituitary, or hypothalamus.The cause involving these sites is prolactinoma (pituitary origin).
  • Negative progesterone challenge test which rules out PCOD (which may sometimes manifest as primary amenorrhea)(Option B ruled out)
  • When next step was done i.e., estrogen, progesterone combined test - lt comes out to be positive i.e., compartment I system (uterus, endometrium and outflow tract) is normal if properly stimulated by estrogen which rules out mullerian agenesis and Ashermann's syndrome.(Option C and A ruled out)

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother of two children has been suffering from amenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has a history of failure of lactation following second delivery but remained asymptomatic thereafter. Skull X-ray shows empty sella diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Empty Sella causes:
    • Congenital incompleteness of the sellar diaphragm.
    • Secondary to surgery/radiotherapy or infarction of pituitary tumor.
    • Secondary to infarction and necrosis of pituitary gland.
  • On X-ray, an empty sella may be seen in either a pituitary tumor or Sheehan's syndrome.
  • Pituitary tumors (micro/macroadenomas) are usually prolactin-secreting and present with galactorrhea + amenorrhea, not with lactational failure, so the most likely diagnosis here is Sheehan's syndrome.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

Sheehan's syndrome:

  • It is the syndrome which results from ischemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitary due to spasm in its arterioles occurring at the time of severe hemorrhage or shock, complicating childbirth.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, normal breasts and scanty pubic hair is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting with primary amenorrhea along with well developed breast and scanty pubic hair and axillary hair leave no doubt regarding Testicular feminisation syndrome as the diagnosis, which c/k/a AIS (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome)

Explanation:

  • During breastfeeding, suckling elevates prolactin. High prolactin acts centrally to suppress the pulsatile secretion of GnRH.(Option B ruled out)
  • Reduced GnRH → decreased LH and FSH release → anovulation → amenorrhea (the essence of lactational amenorrhea).
  • Supporting evidence (from the prompt):
    • In amenorrheic lactating women, giving pulsatile GnRH fully restores pituitary gonadotropin secretion and normal ovarian cycles, confirming that the primary defect is central GnRH suppression.
  • Additional (peripheral) effects of prolactin that reinforce anovulation:
    • Inhibits ovarian progesterone synthesis.
    • Alters the testosterone/dihydrotestosterone ratio, increasing local anti-estrogenic milieu in the ovary.
  • Oxytocin is not the mediator of lactational amenorrhea.(Option C and D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with primary amenorrhea except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Stein-Leventhal Syndrome also known as Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD) is an important cause of Secondary Amenorrhea in young women.
  • Characterized by:
    • Oligomenorrhea (infrequent periods)
    • Secondary amenorrhea (in some cases)
    • Hirsutism, obesity, acne
  • Patients usually have menstruated at some point, though irregularly
  • Primary amenorrhea is not typical in PCOS
  • Testicular Feminisation syndrome, Turners syndrome and Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome are causes of Primary amenorrhea.

Explanation of other options:

  • Testicular Feminization Syndrome (CAIS)(Option A):Karyotype: 46,XY Genetically male, phenotypically female.Normal breast development, sparse/absent pubic and axillary hair,No uterus or upper vagina due to Müllerian inhibition by testes.Testes often found intra-abdominal or in labia.Primary amenorrhea is typical.So it is associated with primary amenorrhea
  • Turner's Syndrome(Option C):Karyotype: 45,XO.Streak gonads → ↓ Estrogen → No secondary sexual characteristicsUterus is present, but no menstruationPrimary amenorrhea is classic.So it is associated with primary amenorrhea
  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome(Option D):Karyotype: 46,XX.Normal secondary sexual characteristics (breast and pubic hair present).Congenital absence of uterus and upper vagina,Ovaries are normal → estrogen production intact.It causes Primary amenorrhea due to absent uterus

choices.text: Developmental defect of the genital tract

questions.text: Primary amenorrhoea is most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary amenorrhea is the failure to attain menarche by age 15 years with normal secondary sexual characters or by 13 years without them.The most common cause of primary amenorrhea is Turner's syndrome (ovarian dysgenesis)
  • Tuberculosis and endocrine abnormalities are causes for secondary amenorrhea and developmental defects of genital tract is a common cause for primary amenorrhea.(Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: Withdrawal bleeding following administration of progestogen in a case of secondary amenorrhoea indicates all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Withdrawal bleeding following administration of progesterone suggests:
    • The uterus is sufficiently primed with estrogen, i.e. production of endogenous estrogen is normal which means. Ovaries and hypothalamic pituitary axes are functioning normally.(Option B and C ruled out)
    • The outflow tract (uterus) is normal and endometrium is responsive to estrogen.
    • There is a defect in production of progesterone (so pregnancy is ruled out).
  • The bleeding rules out pregnancy.(Option A ruled out)
